sp.p: Remove my Pillow —set me up a little—so, speaks squeaking and sickly draw near, pray Gentlemen— What, Sancho too? Ah—thou ungodly— Vermin. Sancho cringes, and shakes his Head.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I'll hang my self, Sir—I can do no more.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: No faith—that's pretty reasonable satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Don Q▪
sp.p: Egh, egh —you wonder, Sir—sat this sudde • Alteration; but this is nothing in the hand of Providence—Thousands that are struck so have dy'd e'er this time—Therefore pray wonder not, but e're I go witness my Will — and so farewel —Are ye ready, Friend?

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, yes; begin when you please.

sp.speaker: Quitter.
sp.p: Methinks his Sense is very clear now.

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: For a minute or two, Madam —but then he falls to strange Extravagancies —I am only here to humour him.

sp.speaker: Don Q.
sp.p: Well first then — egh, egh—without complementing the Worms about my Carkase; for 'tis so lean and scraggy, that they'll have but poor • eeding—I give my chiefest Quality, my Knight Errantry, to the veriest Ideot amongst my Countrymen, that he may have it in his Head to conquer Kingdoms; and that • e may be heartily drubb'd about it as • have been—Quickly, quickly, set it down, I say.

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: I do, I do, Sir. Now pray observe—Now the Fit begins.

sp.speaker: Don Q.
sp.p: In the next place I bequeath my Valour, which in me was but a worse sort of Itch, to all the Cowards and faint-hearted in the Armies abro • d, that they may fight with one another to the end of the VVorld, without knowing why or wherefore.

sp.speaker: Carrasc.
sp.p: That is indeed—a very mad Leg • cy.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Satyrical tho if you mind it.

sp.speaker: Don Q.
sp.p: Egh, egh—Set me a little higher —so—my Conscience and one half of my Brains —I give to the French—that—they may learn to be contented with their own Country —and not le • p like wild Horses into others Men's Ground, till they are secure their Neighbours are not strong enough to lash'em out agen.

sp.speaker: Quitt.
sp.p: These are I confess, more than common Legaci • s.

sp.speaker: Basil▪
sp.p: VVell said again▪ Faith—punc;

sp.speaker: Don Q.
sp.p: To all Statesmen Politicians, Privy-Counsellors, and such like, I bequeath my Integrity of Soul to be an Umpire between their Gain and their Honesty —that when ever they chance to boyl over in 'em, it may cool and allay, like a Wooden-Ladle, when the Fire hath provok'd the Pottage into fury.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: A Solon—A Solon —I say s • ill.

sp.speaker: Don Q.
sp.p: To the great Clergy, and the small —I give my Voice and Lungs, loud and sound as they were at twenty—and a good will to use 'em often —they preach so • aintly now▪ as if they were asham'd of their Trades, and the Priest dozes at Church as often as the Parish.

sp.speaker: Caras.
sp.p: Good agen▪ that was close somewhere too.

sp.speaker: Don Qix.
sp.p: To all Knights of the Curtain, Court-followers, and so forth,—I generally bequeath—the Empire that I propos'd to my self to get, to defray their reasonabl • Expences, 'till they come to Preferment.

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: This is strange, I • xpected he would have chang'd—before now.

sp.speaker: Don Qix.
sp.p: Give me a Tun of Wine there —Bourdeux, Burgundy, Sherry, Shampaign, quick, quick, I grow thirsty. Starts suddenly into a Rage.

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: Oh, now, Sir, mind him▪

sp.speaker: Don Qix.
sp.p: My Soul's upon a Spit alive—I feel it Roasting — hark, it squeaks like a Lobster; some Wine, I say — ye Scoundrel.
sp.stage: Sancho gives him a Bottle, trembling he drinks.
sp.p: Hum—hum—your ears once more, my Friends. Mildly agen. To all Old Batchelors, Drunkards, and Amoreto's above Sixty Five and upwards—I give—humph—I give—a Whore—and a Bottle, Throws his Night-Cap at Quitteria, and the Bottle at Basilius. that they mayn't lose their Character at last, but die as they liv'd in their Calling.

sp.speaker: Notary.
sp.p: I told ye there would be a turn,—see now he's calm again.

sp.speaker: Don Qix.
sp.p: To all Loyal and Wise Citizens that are Married, I soberly bequeath my hollow eyes, and my hearty p • tience, that they may never see the sprouting of their own Horns, nor grumble at the payment of the King's Taxes.

sp.speaker: Caras.
sp.p: That's soberly said enough, I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Don. Quix.
sp.p: You too— that wait here to see my End, must • ave some remembrance; and first to you, Sir, that are newly Married, I frankly give my lepid Age, and limber Experience, that by knowing the folly you have committed now, it may prevent ye from Conjugating a second time.

sp.speaker: Quit.
sp.p: How's that, Sir Knight?

sp.speaker: Don Quix.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no noise, no noise, and ye shall all have something — to you, Madam, I give and tran •• er, and much good may it do ye, my Chastity, to support your own, for a Woman of your Age and Constitution — has not singly enough to keep her honest, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha — the Knight grows merrier as he draws nearer the bottom.

sp.speaker: Don Quix.
sp.p: To you, Sir, that are a great Scholar— and Book-learn'd, I bequeath my Wit and g • ntile Ayr, to help your College Breeding; for search the Universities, and you'll find this Saying true, Th' greatest Clerks are still the awkerd'st Blockheads.

sp.speaker: Caras.
sp.p: Oh, thank ye, Sir, I should be loth to have been left out.

sp.speaker: Don Quix.
sp.p: Lastly, to Sancho there,—

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Ay, a small Purse, if you please, poor honest Sancho, Sir.

sp.speaker: Don Quix.
sp.p: Dull, Saucy, Drunken Sancho, I do bequeath two Gallons a day of my Small-beer—to keep him cool from state of reprobat • on, during his Life—

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Small-beer, Oons, that's small Comfort; well, I'll go get the Rope ready, oh, oh, oh— Weeps, and goes out.

sp.speaker: Don Quix.
sp.p: This is all, Sirs, there's no great need of Executors, or Overseers—the Will can walk alone, without Leading-string • —and now methinks I would fain rest a little.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Do, Sir, and to divert your melancholy, and cheer the fading Spirits, we'll treat ye with some Mus • cal Performance, you us'd to love it, let 'em begin there.

div.stage: Here follows the last Entertainment of Singing ond Dancing, which Ended, Don Quixot sleeps.

div.head: A Dialogue Sung between Lisis and Alti • idora, a Boy and a Girl, suppos'd to be Brother and Sister.

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.l: AH my Dearest Celide,
T • other day I ask'd my Mother,
Why thy Lo • ging chang'd m • st be,
Why not still lie with thy Brother?
I remember well you did,
And I heard too what she said.
Lisis, Y'are a great Boy grown,
Therefore now must lye alone.

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.l: To part us the Custom of Modesty Votes,
Vnless both had Breeches,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.p: Or both had long Coats.

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.l: Ah! what mischief can there be
In these little tyny Breeches,
That can part me thus from thee;
Sures there's Witchcraft in the sti • ches.

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.l: Or what Devil here resides,
That my Petticoat thus hides;
Mother Laughs a • hour or t • o,
When I sometimes ask to know.

sp.speaker: Lysis.
sp.p: Why a He,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.p: And a She,

sp.speaker: Lysis.
sp.p: May not Bed at our Size,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.p: As well as two Girls,

sp.speaker: Lysis.
sp.p: Or as well as two Boys.

sp.speaker: Lysis.
sp.l: I will since I'm kept from you,
Get a Wife as soon as may be,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.l: And I'll get a Husband too,
Three times bigger than my Baby:

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.l: Father to Mamma tells all,
When in Bed they chatting fall.

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.l: And when we are Married too,
We as much as they s • all know.

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.p: T • e Secret will out,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.p: In Comparing of Notes,

sp.speaker: Lisis.
sp.p: What's hid in th • se Breeches,

sp.speaker: Altis.
sp.p: Or lies in these Coats.

q.l: Let's laugh then, and follow our innocent play,
And Kiss, when Mamma is gone out of the way;
For I fear, I fear, we shall cry when we know,
'Tis all that a Brother and Sister may do.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: He's faln asleep, remove him out there softly, 'twill either ease • r end him.

sp.speaker: Quit.
sp.p:
'Tis pity he's condemn'd such Extravagance, the man has Ex
• ellent parts.

sp.speaker: Caras.
sp.p: And on all Theams, excepting his Knight Errantry, most read • and acute.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p:
Come, Sweet, let's take the Air.
Whilst I amongst all great Contentments known,
Looking on thee, am happiest in my own. Curtain falls.
